etymologies: Old English we, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch wij and German wir

definitions: used by a speaker to refer to himself or herself and one or more other people considered together

examples.text: shall we have a drink?

shortDefinitions: used by speaker to refer to himself or herself and one or more other people considered together

definitions: used to refer to the speaker together with other people regarded in the same category

examples.text: nobody knows kids better than we teachers do

shortDefinitions: used to refer to speaker together with other people regarded in same category

definitions: people in general

examples.text: we should eat as varied and well-balanced a diet as possible

definitions: us or our

definitions: used in formal contexts for or by a royal person, or by a writer or editor, to refer to himself or herself

examples.text: in this section we discuss the reasons for this decision

shortDefinitions: used in formal contexts for or by royal person, or by writer or editor

definitions: used condescendingly to refer to the person being addressed

examples.text: how are we today?

shortDefinitions: used condescendingly to refer to person being addressed

etymologies: Old English beran, of Germanic origin; from an Indo-European root shared by Sanskrit bharati, Greek pherein, and Latin ferre

notes.text: Until the 18th century borne and born were simply variant forms of the past participle of bear, used interchangeably with no distinction in meaning. By around 1775, however, the present distinction in use had become established. At that time borne became the standard past participle used in all the senses listed in this dictionary entry, e.g. she has borne you another son, the findings have been borne out, and so on. Born became restricted to just one very common use, which remains the case today: in the passive, without by, as the standard, neutral way to refer to birth: she was born in 1965, he was born lucky, or I was born and bred in Gloucester

definitions: carry the weight of; support

examples.text: the bees form large colonies and need the thick branches of tall trees to bear the weight of their nests

definitions: take responsibility for

examples.text: no one likes to bear the responsibility for such decisions
the expert's fee shall be borne by the tenant

definitions: be able to accept or stand up to

examples.text: it is doubtful whether either of these distinctions would bear scrutiny

shortDefinitions: be able to stand up to

examples.text: she bore the pain stoically

definitions: strongly dislike

examples.text: I can't bear caviar

definitions: (of a person) carry (someone or something)

definitions: (of a vehicle or boat) convey (passengers or cargo)

examples.text: steamboats bear the traveller out of Kerrerra Sound

definitions: have or display as a visible mark or feature

definitions: (of a tree or plant) produce (fruit or flowers)

definitions: turn and proceed in a specified direction

examples.text: bear left and follow the old drove road

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

etymologies: Old English bera, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch beer and German Bär

definitions: a large, heavy mammal that walks on the soles of its feet, having thick fur and a very short tail. Bears are related to the dog family but most species are omnivorous.

notes.text: Family Ursidae: several genera and species

definitions: a teddy bear.
a nickname for Russia.
a large, heavy, cumbersome man

examples.text: a lumbering bear of a man

definitions: a gay or bisexual man with a burly physique and a large amount of body hair

examples.text: a bar frequented by bears

definitions: a rough, bad-mannered, or uncouth person

examples.text: if I make a mistake he goes mad with rage—he's a bear

definitions: something that is very difficult or unpleasant to deal with

examples.text: the car is an absolute bear to operate at low speeds

crossReferenceMarkers: Often contrasted with bull (sense 3 of the noun)
definitions: a person who sells shares hoping to buy them back later at a lower price.
etymologies: said to be from a proverb warning against ‘selling the bear's skin before one has caught the bear’

phrases.text: like a bear with a sore head

examples.text: all parents dream of children who tidy their bedrooms without being asked

etymologies: mid 16th century: from Spanish huracán, probably from Taino hurakán ‘god of the storm’

etymologies: Middle English (also denoting astrology): from Old French astronomie, from Latin astronomia, from Greek, from astronomos (adjective) ‘star-arranging’

notes.text: In ancient times, observation of the sun, moon, stars, and planets formed the basis of timekeeping and navigation. Astronomy was greatly furthered by the invention of the telescope, but modern observations are made in all parts of the spectrum, including X-ray and radio frequencies, using terrestrial and orbiting instruments and space probes

definitions: the branch of science that deals with celestial objects, space, and the physical universe as a whole

examples.text: the project is expected to represent a giant leap forward in astronomy

shortDefinitions: branch of science which deals with celestial objects

etymologies: late Old English herebeorg ‘shelter, refuge’, herebeorgian ‘occupy shelter’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch herberge and German Herberge, also to French auberge ‘inn’; see also harbinger
